Heathrow Airport E-commerce Website

Project Overview

The project was initiated with the reception of a design recommendation pack from an external supplier. The main objective of the project was to revamp the existing e-commerce website, incorporating the findings from the analysis of the recommendation pack. The team aimed to effectively evaluate the design recommendations and translate them into actionable items of work.

Challenge

The materials provided included the UI redesign of the current site. However, there were numerous discrepancies that needed to be addressed. These discrepancies involved recognised technical limitations that had to be considered, missing user flows that met the actual user needs, and opportunities that held value for the business. Due to these issues, a careful identification of the key areas that needed attention was required. This identification process was essential in order to devise a design solution that effectively revamped the website and addressed these challenges.

Year

2023

Lead Time

Phase 1: 8 weeks
Phase 2: 3 months

Services

Design Planning, User Research, UX Design

Tools Used

Figma, Zeplin, Mural, ADO

Methodology

Gap Analysis

The UI screens of the existing website were audited and compared with the provided recommendations. Then the screens were broken down into components to analyse the gaps in the design style guide.

    Purpose:
  • To address the differences of the visual elements and functionalities
  • To identify and evaluate gaps in missing variations and pages
  • Allow more accurate estimation of future phases of work
Feasibility Check

It was completed in a series of meetings with the Technical Lead and the Project Lead to understand the feasibility of each items to help scope the approach for the following phase.

Desirability Check

It was carried out in multiple meetings involving the Product Owner team to ensure that the items to be implemented have a positive effect on the business, retail partners, and customers' needs.

Discovery

Planning

Feasibility Check

It was completed in a series of meetings with the Technical Lead and the Project Lead to understand the feasibility of each items to help scope the approach for the following phase.

Design

Design Testing

In the UAT phase, the website has been thoroughly tested from the UX perspective, alongside technical QA testing, to ensure the functionality and user experience of the product. This involved examining the overall design consistency, verifying proper alignment and spacing, evaluating the colour scheme and typography, and validating responsiveness across different devices and screen sizes. I then logged the defects in Azure DevOps, including steps to reproduce and priority levels. This facilitated effective communication with the development team for timely issue resolution.

Usability Testing

Prior to the website launch, we conducted usability testing with 8 key stakeholders who regularly use the product. These stakeholders acted as proxy users, providing feedback on the usability of the website on behalf of real users. It provided valuable insights for quick-win solutions to address user pain points and future iterations, ensuring a user-friendly experience.
